sections.section_text: No statement made by any person to a police officer in the course of an investigation shall be signed by the person making it, and such statement shall not be used as evidence except as provided in the Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam, 2023. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: No Inducement to Be Offered
sections.section_text: No police officer shall offer any inducement, threat, or promise to any person to make a statement during an investigation. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Recording of Confessions and Statements
sections.section_text: Any Magistrate may record a confession or statement made to him during an investigation, and such recording shall be done in the manner prescribed. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Search by Police Officer
sections.section_text: A police officer may conduct a search during an investigation if he has reasonable grounds for believing that anything necessary for the investigation may be found in a particular place. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: When Officer in Charge of Police Station May Require Another to Issue Search-Warrant
sections.section_text: An officer in charge of a police station may require another officer to issue a search-warrant in certain cases. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Procedure When Investigation Cannot Be Completed in Twenty-Four Hours
sections.section_text: If an investigation cannot be completed within 24 hours, the police officer shall produce the accused before a Magistrate for further detention orders. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Report of Investigation by Subordinate Police Officer
sections.section_text: A subordinate police officer conducting an investigation shall report the results to the officer in charge of the police station. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Release of Accused When Evidence Deficient
sections.section_text: If evidence is deficient, the police officer may release the accused on bail or discharge him. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Cases to Be Sent to Magistrate, When Evidence Is Sufficient
sections.section_text: When evidence is sufficient, the police officer shall forward the accused to a Magistrate. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Complainant and Witnesses Not to Be Required to Accompany Police Officer and Not to Be Subjected to Restraint
sections.section_text: Complainants and witnesses shall not be required to accompany a police officer or be subjected to restraint. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Diary of Proceedings in Investigation
sections.section_text: Every police officer making an investigation shall maintain a diary of proceedings in the prescribed form. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Report of Police Officer on Completion of Investigation
sections.section_text: (1) Every investigation under this Chapter shall be completed without unnecessary delay, and as soon as it is completed, the officer in charge of the police station shall forward to a Magistrate empowered to take cognizance of the offence on a police report, a report in the form prescribed by the State Government, stating— (a) the names of the parties; (b) the nature of the information; (c) the names of the persons who appear to be acquainted with the circumstances of the case; (d) whether any offence appears to have been committed and, if so, by whom; (e) whether the accused has been arrested; (f) whether he has been released on his bond and, if so, whether with or without sureties; (g) whether he has been forwarded in custody under section 170; (h) whether the report of medical examination of the woman has been attached, where investigation relates to an offence under section 64, section 65, section 66, section 67, section 68, section 70, section 71, section 74, section 75, section 76, section 77, section 78, section 79 or section 351 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023. (2) The officer shall also communicate, in such manner as may be prescribed by the State Government, the action taken by him, to the person, if any, by whom the information relating to the commission of the offence was first given. (3) Where a superior officer of police has been appointed under section 175, the report shall, in any case in which the State Government by general or special order so directs, be submitted through that officer, and he may, pending the orders of the Magistrate, direct the officer in charge of the police station to make further investigation. (4) Whenever it appears from a report forwarded under this section that the accused has been released on his bond, the Magistrate shall make such order for the discharge of such bond or otherwise as he thinks fit. (5) When such report is in respect of a case to which section 170 applies, the police officer shall forward to the Magistrate along with the report— (a) all documents or relevant extracts thereof on which the prosecution proposes to rely other than those already sent to the Magistrate during investigation; (b) the statements recorded under section 161 of all the persons whom the prosecution proposes to examine as its witnesses. (6) If the police officer is of opinion that any part of any such statement is not relevant to the subject-matter of the proceedings or that its disclosure to the accused is not essential in the interests of justice and is inexpedient in the public interest, he shall indicate that part of the statement and append a note requesting the Magistrate to exclude that part from the copies to be granted to the accused and stating his reasons for making such request.

sections.section_title: Police to Inquire and Report on Suicide, etc.
sections.section_text: A police officer shall inquire into cases of suicide or death under suspicious circumstances and report to the Magistrate. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Power to Summon Persons
sections.section_text: A police officer may summon any person to appear before him if such person’s presence is necessary for the investigation. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Inquiry by Magistrate into Cause of Death
sections.section_text: A Magistrate may hold an inquiry into the cause of death in cases reported under section 174. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

chapters.chapter_name: Jurisdiction of the Criminal Courts in Inquiries and Trials

sections.section_title: Ordinary Place of Inquiry and Trial
sections.section_text: Every offence shall ordinarily be inquired into and tried by a Court within whose local jurisdiction it was committed.

sections.section_title: Place of Inquiry or Trial
sections.section_text: (1) When it is uncertain in which of several local areas an offence was committed, or where an offence is committed partly in one local area and partly in another, or where an offence is a continuing one, and continues to be committed in more local areas than one, or where it consists of several acts done in different local areas, it may be inquired into or tried by a Court having jurisdiction over any of such local areas. (2) When an act is an offence by reason of anything which has been done and of a consequence which has ensued, the offence may be inquired into or tried by a Court within whose local jurisdiction such thing has been done or such consequence has ensued.

sections.section_title: Offence Triable Where Act Is Done or Consequence Ensues
sections.section_text: When an act is an offence by reason of anything which has been done and of a consequence which has ensued, the offence may be inquired into or tried by a Court within whose local jurisdiction such thing has been done or such consequence has ensued. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Place of Trial Where Act Is an Offence by Reason of Relation to Other Offence
sections.section_text: When an act is an offence by reason of its relation to any other act which is also an offence, the first-mentioned offence may be inquired into or tried by a Court within whose local jurisdiction either act was done. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Place of Trial in Case of Certain Offences
sections.section_text: Specific offences, such as those involving theft, robbery, or criminal misappropriation, may be tried in the jurisdiction where the offence was committed or where the stolen property was possessed. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Offences Committed by Letters, etc.
sections.section_text: Offences committed through letters, electronic communication, or similar means may be tried in the jurisdiction where the communication was sent or received. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Offence Committed on Journey or Voyage
sections.section_text: When an offence is committed during a journey or voyage, it may be inquired into or tried by a Court through or into whose local jurisdiction the person or thing passed during the journey or voyage. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Place of Trial for Offences Triable Together
sections.section_text: When a person is accused of the commission of any offence by reason of anything which has been done, and of any consequence which has ensued, such offence may be inquired into or tried by a Court within whose local jurisdiction any such thing has been done or any such consequence has ensued, and where several offences are triable together, they may be tried in any Court having jurisdiction over any one of such offences.

sections.section_title: Power to Order Cases to Be Tried in Different Sessions Divisions
sections.section_text: The State Government may direct that any case or class of cases be tried in a different sessions division for the interests of justice. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: High Court to Decide, in Case of Doubt, District Where Inquiry or Trial Shall Take Place
sections.section_text: When there is doubt regarding the jurisdiction of a Court, the High Court may decide the district where the inquiry or trial shall take place. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Power to Issue Summons or Warrant for Offence Committed Beyond Local Jurisdiction
sections.section_text: A Magistrate may issue a summons or warrant for an offence committed beyond his local jurisdiction if he has reason to believe the offence was committed within his jurisdiction. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Offence Committed Outside India
sections.section_text: When an offence is committed outside India by a citizen of India or on an Indian ship or aircraft, it may be inquired into or tried in India as if it had been committed within the local jurisdiction of the Court. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Receipt of Evidence Relating to Offences Committed Outside India
sections.section_text: When an offence is committed outside India, evidence relating to such offence may be received by a Court in India as if the offence had been committed within its jurisdiction. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

chapters.chapter_name: Conditions Requisite for Initiation of Proceedings

sections.section_title: Cognizance of Offences by Magistrates
sections.section_text: (1) Subject to the provisions of this Chapter, any Magistrate of the first class, and any Magistrate of the second class specially empowered in this behalf under sub-section (2), may take cognizance of any offence— (a) upon receiving a complaint of facts which constitute such offence; (b) upon a police report of such facts; (c) upon information received from any person other than a police officer, or upon his own knowledge, that such offence has been committed. (2) The Chief Judicial Magistrate may empower any Magistrate of the second class to take cognizance under sub-section (1) of such offences as are within his competence to inquire into or try.

sections.section_title: Transfer on Application of the Accused
sections.section_text: When a Magistrate takes cognizance of an offence under clause (c) of sub-section (1) of section 190, the accused shall be informed and may apply for transfer of the case to another Magistrate. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Making Over of Cases to Magistrates
sections.section_text: A Chief Judicial Magistrate may make over a case to any competent Magistrate for inquiry or trial. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Cognizance of Offences by Courts of Session
sections.section_text: Except as otherwise expressly provided by this Sanhita or by any other law for the time being in force, no Court of Session shall take cognizance of any offence as a Court of original jurisdiction unless the case has been committed to it by a Magistrate under this Sanhita.

sections.section_title: Additional and Assistant Sessions Judges to Try Cases Made Over to Them
sections.section_text: An Additional Sessions Judge or Assistant Sessions Judge may try cases made over to them by the Sessions Judge. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Prosecution for Contempt of Lawful Authority of Public Servants, for Offences Against Public Justice and for Offences Relating to Documents Given in Evidence
sections.section_text: (1) No Court shall take cognizance— (a) (i) of any offence punishable under sections 178 to 181, section 183, section 184, section 186, section 189 or section 353 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023; or (ii) of any abetment of, or attempt to commit, such offence; or (iii) of any criminal conspiracy to commit such offence, except on the complaint in writing of the public servant concerned or of some other public servant to whom he is administratively subordinate; (b) (i) of any offence punishable under sections 206 to 211, section 213, section 214, section 216, section 217 or section 222 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023, when such offence is alleged to have been committed in, or in relation to, any proceeding in any Court; or (ii) of any offence described in section 332 or section 353 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023, when such offence is alleged to have been committed in respect of a document produced or given in evidence in a proceeding in any Court; or (iii) of any criminal conspiracy to commit, or attempt to commit, or the abetment of, any offence specified in sub-clause (i) or sub-clause (ii), except on the complaint in writing of that Court or by such officer of the Court as that Court may authorise in writing in this behalf, or of some other Court to which that Court is subordinate. (2) Where a complaint has been made by a public servant under clause (a) of sub-section (1), any authority to which he is administratively subordinate may order the withdrawal of the complaint and send a copy of such order to the Court; and upon its receipt by the Court, no further proceedings shall be taken on the complaint: Provided that no such withdrawal shall be ordered if the trial in the Court of first instance has been fully or partly held and the Court is satisfied that justice demands the continuation of the proceedings. (3) In the case of a complaint made under clause (b) of sub-section (1), the Court may, for reasons to be recorded, take cognizance of an offence on a complaint made by any person other than the Court or its authorised officer, if it is satisfied that the interests of justice so require.

sections.section_title: Prosecution for Offences Against the State and for Criminal Conspiracy to Commit Such Offence
sections.section_text: No Court shall take cognizance of offences against the State or criminal conspiracy to commit such offences except with the previous sanction of the Central or State Government. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Prosecution of Judges and Public Servants
sections.section_text: No Court shall take cognizance of an offence alleged to have been committed by a Judge or public servant while acting in the discharge of official duties except with the previous sanction of the appropriate authority. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Prosecution for Offences Against Marriage
sections.section_text: No Court shall take cognizance of offences against marriage under the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023, except upon a complaint by the aggrieved person or specified relatives. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]

sections.section_title: Prosecution for Defamation
sections.section_text: No Court shall take cognizance of an offence of defamation except upon a complaint made by the person aggrieved by the offence. [Full text available in official BNSS 2023 document.]
